Not only can you visit the exclusive art collections, archaeological artefacts, and items of ethnographic interest, but you can also visit some of the more significant areas of the Apostolic Palaces which contain some of the most famous artistic masterpieces of all times and some of the greatest treasures of the past.

In the heart of Rome, artistic beauty and spiritual afflatus join together.

Retrace the steps traced in ages past by the Roman Emperors, discover the traces left by the Christian martyrs, and follow in the footsteps of so many Saints who have walked before us in these same streets. Contemplate the stories of the Gospel and of those who put it into practice in a heroic manner, as told by the works of art and by the architectural masterpieces.

Rome preserves the memory of Gospel events through so many relics kept in various basilicas and churches. Discover the most significant Christian relics along a path that starts at the Basilica of Holy Cross in Jerusalem and ends at the Basilica of Saint Mary Major. Relive events from the life of Jesus and of the Apostles. Get a taste of the Holy Land here in Rome, in anticipation of an actual pilgrimage to the places of the Gospel in the Holy Land.

The Vatican Gardens occupy about two thirds of the surface area of Vatican City. The Popes have come to relax and meditate here since the year 1279 AD. You can admire the natural beauty and architectural wonders of the Vatican Gardens with a guided visit. Or, you can choose to have your visit in an unprecedented and sustainable fashion: on board a panoramic minibus where the silence of the "green heart" of the Vatican will permeate an evocative tour along paths of art, nature, and faith.

Enchanting at any time of the year, the Pontifical Villas of Castel Gandolfo are a unique balance between nature and art. Come appreciate the treasures that the Gardens of the Pontifical Villas offer. Together with Villa Cybo and Villa Barberini, the Castel Gandolfo Residence forms the complex of Pontifical Villas with their splendid gardens and marvelous park.

Admire the Apostolic Palace, which for centuries was used as a summer residence of the Popes, and is now a museum. Take a journey through time as you admire the paintings, the relics, the liturgical garb and the uniforms.

The magnificent 18th century façade by Carlo Maderno and the Colonnade by Bernini symbolically embrace pilgrims arriving in the Eternal City. The embrace of Saint Peter's Basilica welcomes you for your visit as you come and discover the endless history of faith and charitable works.
tsr_1: Admire not only the magnificence of the building and the beauty of the artwork, but come follow along a path of faith and spirituality. As you walk through the naves of the Basilica, stop to visit the side chapels and listen to the Gospel message that the works of art convey. As for example Michelangelo's Pietà, which not only is a masterpiece of all time, but also assists us in contemplating the Paschal mystery.

tsr_0: The Basilica of Saint John Lateran, defined “Mater et Caput” of all the churches in Rome and in the world, is the Cathedral of Rome and the episcopal seat of the Holy Father.
tsr_1: You'll discover the Lateran Complex, which comprehends more than one place of great interest: the Basilica and the Cloister, the Baptistery, and the Holy Stairs with the “Sancta Sanctorum” Papal Chapel.
tsr_2: Discovery the beauty and the history of one of the most evocative places in Rome!

tsr_0: OF SANTA MARIA IN VIA LATA
The Basilica Santa Maria in via Lata preserves the memory of an important piece of the two thousand year history of Christianity in the Eternal City.

Founded atop ancient origins, the church was built over an earlier church from the 7th or 8th century, and eventually was given a baroque style. According to tradition, the Apostles Peter and Paul dwelt here during the years of their imprisonment in Rome.
In the crypt, remains of a large Roman period edifice are still visible; in the 7th century, it was transformed into a place of worship.

The Carcer Tullianum is one of the most fascinating archeological monuments from the era of the Roman republic. It contains a wealth of art, archeology and history. It has also become a place of Christian worship, and is situated beneath the church of Saint Joseph of the Carpenters. And seeing that it faces the Roman Forum, it offers one of the most evocative views of ancient Rome. With the assistance of some of the most recent technologies, you will discover the place where, according to tradition, Saint Peter was imprisoned.
During this visit, you will be able to admire the exceptional historical stratification, which tells us about every day life in ancient Rome and its development over time.

Carcer Tullianum: the maximum security prison of ancient Rome where enemies of state were imprisoned; Colosseum: where cruel games of Imperial Rome were held; Roman Forum: the social, commercial and religious hub of ancient Rome from the first pages of its history; Palatine Hill, place where this city was born around the middle of the eighth century BC.

The Catacombs of Rome are a network of tunnels carved out of tuff, at times on several levels. As you progress through this network of corridors, rooms and underground halls, you will be inevitably taken in not only by evocative scenes both from the Bible and from every day life in Rome, but also by a world of symbols, some of which are painted as frescoes, others which are carved into the stone as graffiti.
The city of Rome is an open air museum, which you can explore in relaxation while you take in the amazing view, on board the Vatican&Rome Open Bus.
tsr_1: An authentic journey into the heart of the City. You'll be able to hop on and off at any of the stops along the way, strategically placed in the most interesting areas of the city. A multi-language audio guide will assist in enriching your knowledge of Rome's history and of its wonders.

tsr_0: OMNIA Vatican&Rome was born from the decades-long experience of Opera Romana Pellegrinaggi (ORP), an activity of the Diocese of Rome which was founded in 1933 to accompany Italian and foreign pilgrims along the journeys of the Spirit in Italy and around the world, offering adequate spiritual and technical-organizational assistance.
tsr_1: ORP has been carrying out a precious pastoral service for over 85 years, accompanying hundreds of thousands of faithful to the shrines of Lourdes and Fatima, to the Holy Land, to Turkey, to Santiago de Compostela and to many other places and countries in Europe and in the world.

tsr_0: “Rome is the capital of the world. The entire history of the world is tied to this city, and I believe I was born a second time, I believe I was truly risen, the day I set foot in Rome. Its beauties have gradually raised me up to their own heights.”

Experience Rome in all its nooks and crannies

Far from the clamor of the more famous sites, you can also discover a less well known Rome with hidden corners and alternate routes compared to the traditional ones. Take a stroll to discover hidden jewels both in and around the city center. Hear stories and untold peculiarities about churches, museums, districts, parks, basilicas, basements and terraces.

There is no imagining Rome without the Jewish community. Already in the second century, the community had settled between Trastevere and the opposite bank, where the Ghetto was established in the 16th century. A corner of the Eternal City where the most important memories of the Roman Jewish tradition are preserved. In the Portico of Octavia we remember the Roman period, in Piazza delle Cinque Scole the synagogues the rituals of which were forged by Jews from different countries, and in front of the Great Temple we witness the vitality of today's community. We will see traces of the forced isolation that this community suffered under the Nazi-fascist persecution. A thought provoking journey that calls to mind dramatic and painful stages of history.

“Nullus agenti dies longus est” - no day is long for those who work - said Seneca, and Rome has continued to work for millennia, maintaining in its traditions that uniqueness that has characterized not only its history, but also its social and urban planning. There are many streets dedicated to ancient crafts, many places where you can rediscover the flavors of both cultural and gastronomic tradition. A journey of discovery in the alleys of the center amidst art, history, Christianity, tradition and curiosity.

In 2007 ORP created Roma Cristiana, a specialized structure dedicated to welcoming visitors from all nations, languages and religious beliefs to the Eternal City, providing tour services to the main places of history, art and spirituality in the city of Rome.

In this context, the OMNIA Vatican & Rome project was born in collaboration with Roma Capitale and the Zètema Cultural Project. OMNIA is an card with integrated services that allow you to visit the most beautiful sites of the city: Vatican Museums, Sistine Chapel, Saint Peter's Basilica, Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill, Basilica of Saint John Lateran and Cloister, also giving access to transportation on the Vatican & Rome Open Bus and on public transportation in the city.
The Ostiense Neighborhood and the Centrale Montemartini
The Fountain of the Four Rivers

The initiatives intend to offer young people, families, students and teachers a training model aimed at discovering our cultural, historical, artistic, religious and environmental heritage in a responsible way.
tsr_1: Visiting, reflecting, discovering and learning are things that cannot be held back from the younger generation.

tsr_0: Among Rome's world records, we can count the highest concentration of obelisks in the world. Both Egyptian and Roman obelisks soar high in the Roman sky among the streets and squares of Rome. If they were a religious symbol for the Egyptians, for the Romans they became a symbol of power, victory and supremacy.

During the Renaissance the obelisks represented an element of artistic and architectural expression, and began to constitute a Christian symbol of upsurge towards God, reason for which they were placed nearby the great Christian Basilicas.

The Ostiense neighborhood, even if considered an area outside the city center that has degraded over time, did however play an important role both as an ancient access to the city in connection to the port of Ostia, and as a point of reference for artistic and social activities.
tsr_1: Witness the rise of the first industrial district of Rome, as well as the consequent redevelopment of industrial buildings which were transformed into cultural spaces. Such is the story of the Montemartini power plant, the first public plant in Rome for the production of electrical power.

tsr_0: The Park of the Aqueducts is a very lively place. The aqueducts were a masterpiece of engineering in ancient times, requiring a precision in their inclination down to the centimeter in order to succeed in bringing water into the city. The park has always been considered one of the green lungs of the city, a pleasant destination for taking a stroll amidst ancient Roman ruins.

During the night visit you will have the opportunity to immerse yourself in the unique atmosphere of the Vatican Museums, emphasized by the magic of the evening. Evening music concerts create a suggestive atmosphere.

The Lateran Apostolic Palace stands adjacent to the Basilica of Saint John Lateran, “Mater et Caput” of all the churches of Rome and the world, in one of the historic districts of the city. Frescoed vaults, magnificent ceilings, the charm and uniqueness of the rooms contribute to making private events hosted within even more exclusive.

Retrace the history of Rome's political institutions from the republican era up to the period of fascism and the birth of the Italian Republic in 1946.

Centuries-old historical places deserve to be known and appreciated in order to better understand the political identity of the city of Rome: a unique city that owes its intangible cultural heritage to this heterogeneous set of institutions and political realities.

In a small paradise far from the noise of the city, admire the beauty of Villa Borghese and see the many transformations that it has undergone over the centuries. Splendid statues surrounded by greenery, luxuriant vegetation, the lake with its rich ecosystem will make for a pleasant visit painted with colors and imbued with floral scents.

Through careful and curious observation of clues, kids and their families will become true hunters of art as they recreate a mini safari by catching reproductions of animals hidden along the streets of the historic center.

A fun, captivating and original way to explore the city, learn about its history, its protagonists and the works of art. It will be a sort of role-playing game in which each child becomes a “story hunter”, with the ability to then pass these stories onto his or her peers.
The two lions and the capitoline she-wolf

Our city is full of stories and characters that intertwine over time… why not get to know them by playing a game? Kids will be involved in a visit along via dei Fori Imperiali, with an interactive historical themed treasure hunt. They will solve puzzles, overcome tests and go in search of clues that they will find along the way: an adventure filled story full of action as well as culture and typical traditions of ancient Rome.
A way of discovering the history behind Via dei Fori Imperiali, the Colosseum and the places of ancient Rome.

Its timeless beauty and the amazement that the Eternal City generates in each of us. Its uniqueness lies precisely in the central role it has historically played and we can breathe its entire history by walking through its streets, visiting its monuments and discovering the most hidden places. We will visit what are considered the symbols of the city, an expression of culture, Christianity, history and tradition, getting lost in and letting ourselves be carried away by the charm of the era that was.

The Villa of Wonders: Villa Torlonia

The Lateran Palace was the official residence of the popes for many centuries. Considering its history, it has a lot to offer from an artistic, cultural and religious point of view. Here each room you visit has frescoed vaults, magnificent ceilings, fine tapestries, and paintings by great masters. You can also find fine antique furniture, for example in the private Papal apartment. This visit is an opportunity to experience and learn about both the history of the Church and that of the city of Rome. Quite a bit to appreciate from the Lateran Palace!

We issue railway, air and sea tickets; specifically, we offer discounted prices and concessions up to 50% off of High Speed, Freccia Rossa/Freccia Argento trains.

The focus of this itinerary is on those icons revered over the centuries by the Roman people, that are among the oldest extant icons in the world, and are often considered to have somewhat of a miraculous nature, or to tell a story that is none less than miraculous. Take a journey through faith and devotion. As objects of devotion, the icons have been carried in procession, invoked for healing, and still today are a living memory of Mary, Mother of us all, and of Jesus, son of God and son of Mary. At Santa Maria in via Lata, we will remember Saint Luke who dwelled there, and who was the first iconographer in history. At Santa Maria in Aracoeli, we will invoke the Madonna Advocata. At Santa Francesca Romana we will pay homage to the oldest known marian icon, “Our Lady of Comfort”. And last but not least, we will meet the patroness of Rome, Mary “Salus Populi Romani” in the Basilica of Saint Mary Major, whom the Popes themselves greet before and after their journeys abroad.

Traveling along the banks of the Tiber aboard a boat, explore Rome from a unique viewpoint. Then on board the Vatican&Rome Open Bus admire Rome with a view from above. With the support of a guide, discover fountains such as the Fountain of the Four Rivers in Piazza Navona, the Trevi Fountain and many less well known fountains hidden in various corners of the city. An extraordinary journey in which to experience the city in a unique way.

Discover some of the incredible treasures that Rome preserves such as the ancient mosaics present in various churches. Starting at the Basilica of Saint Mary Major, with the cycle of marian mosaics from the fifth century, as well as those of the Triumphal Arch and the Apse, which eloquently testify to a Byzantine presence in Rome; and arriving at the Basilica of Santa Maria in Cosmedin, still officiated today with the Byzantine-Melkite rite as evidence of the ancient Oriental origins of the area.

Discover the countless commemorative plaques scattered throughout the center of town, commemorating specific people or events. In Rome many artists, writers, poets, and other significant people were born, or at least lived for some time. Great artists whom the city remembers "eternally" with marble plaques.
We offer all kinds of catering at selected facilities with the possibility of a box lunch and / or catering service at exclusive locations

Splendid richly decorated rooms, a well-kept courtyard and a strategic position a stone's throw from the Pantheon and Piazza Navona are aspects that mark the most important occasions with style and originality.

Open the doors of the Vatican Museums together with the keyholder, the owner of all the 2797 keys of the Vatican! There are about ten “custodians” who take turns opening the wonderful rooms of the Vatican Museums to the public every day.

Delve into the past in an exclusive visit to the most important burial places of the first Christians, usually closed to the general public. A unique opportunity to experience underground Rome that would be otherwise almost impossible to experience.
An unwonted and authentic Venue for an event “on the move” on board an Open Bus in the streets of Rome.
